fields.Title of Presentation: Theorizing Education Educationally: The Role of Speculation
fields.Description/Abstract: As an area of practice, study, and research, education is often conceptualized as a loose collection of phenomena and concerns to be investigated and theorized by methods and disciplines external to it. Could education be defined constitutively as a domain and theorized in a way that is itself educational? This paper, which is part of the special issue on “Theoretical Research in Education,” considers a common, general way of accomplishing this. It follows the example of Hannah Arendt, who, in her 1958 ‘The Crisis in Education,’ takes “the relation between grown-ups and children in general” as her starting initial premise. She develops this claim variously, but at one point compares a child’s “process of becoming” to that of a kitten—with the first being a question of historicity and natality, and the second, of biology. John Dewey’s ‘Democracy and Education,’ and two texts central to German-language canon—Siegfried Bernfeld’s 1925 ‘Sisyphus, or the Limits of Education,’ and F.D.E. Schleiermacher’s 1826 ‘Outlines of the Art of Education’—also offer analogous intergenerational definitions and also develop them in a broadly speculative manner. Framing these as ways of engaging in theoretical research. These ways of theorizing, this paper concludes that investigations of this kind, allow for a constitutive understanding of education, one established from an educational perspective, and one suited specifically to the way that education, as Schleiermacher himself noted, is “not self-contained, and always presupposes something that it can’t decide on its own.”
